results.title: Health is their business
results.creator_credit: W. H. Shepherd, Shan Benson and Australian Commonwealth Film Unit
results.brief_description: The manufacture of drugs, particularly “biologicals” at the Commonwealth Serum Laboratories. Since the laboratories were established in 1916 they have maintained a steady supply of vaccines and drugs which have reduced the child death rate enormously - almost eliminating many diseases [sic]. The production of Salk vaccine and penicillin is shown, the rigid series of tests on each batch of doses, and the extraction of spider venom for research on an anti-venene.
results.creator_credit_for_label: W. H. Shepherd, Shan Benson and Australian Commonwealth Film Unit

results.title: Sydney today
results.creator_credit: Jean Halliday, Lex Halliday and Australian Instructional Films
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Modern social studies”
Adapted from film of the same title originally produced for Textile Cones and Tubes Ltd. A travelogue of Sydney ranging from city streets to surfing beaches, centres of learning to expanding industries and homes to harbour activities.

results.title: Pond insects
results.brief_description: The diving water beetle, the mayfly, and the dragonfly represent this group of insects. Their life cycles are portrayed as well as their food habits and struggle for existence.

results.title: Wooden wealth
results.brief_description: Tells the story of timber from the felling of the trees to its ultimate use in the production of a variety of different things such as houses, paper and toys. Also, shows something of the conservation work carried out by the Forestry Officers.

results.title: Seeds of destruction
results.creator_credit: George E. Brewer Jnr, New York Zoological Society and The Conservation Foundation
results.brief_description:
Episode number 4 of Series “The Living Earth”.

This film illustrates what happens when any one of the vital links in the “chain of life” is broken. Unscientific lumbering practices, devastating forest fires, uncontrolled wind and water erosion, overworked land, and roaring floods are shown as the agents which can destroy the world unless humans begin to act to combat the havoc caused by thoughtless use of natural resources.

results.title: Coping: isolation and transience in a new Australian mining town
results.creator_credit: Phillip Robertson, Malcolm Otton and Film Australia
results.brief_description: A study of four women’s lives in the remote mining community of Leinster, Western Australia. They are all members of the Country Women’s Association, a club which provides them with companionship in a strange environment. Details the daily life and social activities of the women and their families who live closely together in this remote town. Narrated by Philip Robertson.

results.title: Getting away
results.brief_description: Gladys Riggs, bored with her family life in a caravan park, plans to “escape” with a travelling salesman. However, her attempts are thwarted when her son decides to come along. Based on a short story by G. Dorothy Thomas.

results.title: Islam and the sciences
results.creator_credit: Peter De Normanville, Douglas Gordon and Phoenix Films
results.brief_description: A comprehensive look at the influence of the Islamic world on the sciences from the seventh century A.D. to the present. Surveying the history of its scientific and technological advances in the fields of astronomy, mathematics, water resources and power generation, time measurement, geography and cartography, chemistry and medicine.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Peter De Normanville, Douglas Gordon and Phoenix Films

results.title: Trapping and heading
results.brief_description:
Episode no. 3 of Series “Pele: the master and his method”
Demonstrates trapping skills with cushioning, inside and outside-of-the-foot traps, sole and instep traps and trapping on the run. Also shows a variety of heading techniques including how to play heading tennis.
